Comments_List: Mathematics and statistics within the context of biological experiments and design
Data analysis and estimation of parameters.
How to analyze data and determine the statistical methods that should be used
Lectures notes are not well organized

Professor Carson provided incredibly detailed notes and resources to guide the course. Lectures consisted of lots of examples and were recorded so that they could be revisited during homework/studying for exams
I think Rich does a very good job at explaining the material. The TF sessions are also very helpful. Less work would be appreciated from a grad's student perspective.

This course requires the student to have some preliminary (functional) knowledge of statistics, calculus and computing. For non-engineers, it is important to evaluate where your knowledge stands in these topics.  The course is a lot of work but I bet worth it!  I asked the course instructor if statistics and calculus experience from 5+ years ago and no computing experience would be enough for me to make it through the class (emphasising I barely remembered anything). It is not, I later discussed with the course TF and realized I was way over my head. I think this course is very beneficial and a great resource. I wish I had been better informed so I could have taken this course down the line after some more experience.
It covers a broad range of fields, but it is not very engaging and the content could be better explained with examples.
Yes, I would recommend to any other BME graduate students. The work was tough at times but the professor and TF provided guidance that allowed us to succeed, I learned a lot in this class.

I asked the course instructor if statistics and calculus experience from 5+ years ago and no computing experience would be enough for me to make it through the class (emphasising I barely remembered anything). If they are looking for a broad review of biomedical statistical principles, then it is a good class.
